abstract.text: The base object that contains information about how to configure an augmented reality session.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: defines a base class for the different options you can configure in your AR experience.

All AR configurations establish a correspondence between the real world that the device inhabits and the virtual 3D-coordinate space, where you model content. When your app mixes virtual content with a live-camera image, the user experiences the illusion that your virtual content is part of the real world.

To acquire the live-camera imagery, ARKit manages a camera-capture pipeline for you. Depending on the configuration you choose, it determines the cameras that capture imagery, and which camera feed the app displays.
AR apps recognize real-world regions of interest. At runtime, ARKit generates an

for a real-world object it recognizes, which allows an app to refer to its details, such as size and physical location. The configuration you choose determines the kinds of real-world objects ARKit recognizes and makes available to your app.
yourself; instead, instantiate one of its subclasses.
For more information about the camera-capture pipeline, see

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
An object that specifies the position and orientation of an item in the physical environment.
A configuration that tracks human body poses, planar surfaces, and images using the rear-facing camera.
The base object that contains information about how to configure an augmented reality session.
Types of optional frame features you can enable in your app.
Options that enable ARKit to detect the shape of the physical environment.
A video size and frame rate specification for use with an AR session.
Options for how ARKit constructs a scene coordinate system based on real-world device motion.
An object that enables you to alter the appearance of a frame’s captured image.
The set of active semantics on the frame.
A Boolean value specifying whether ARKit analyzes scene lighting in captured camera images.
A Boolean value indicating whether the current device supports this session configuration class.
A Boolean value that specifies whether to capture audio during the AR session.
Provides a 4K video format if the device and configuration support it.
Returns a video format that the framework recommends for high-resolution-still-image capture.
The set of video capture formats available on the current device.
Checks whether a particular feature is supported.
Video format of the session output.
Enables high dynamic range (HDR) for the session’s camera feed.
A value specifying how the session maps real-world device motion into a 3D scene coordinate system.
A configuration that tracks facial movement and expressions using the front camera.
A configuration that tracks locations with GPS, map data, and a device’s compass.
A configuration that tracks known images using the rear-facing camera.
A configuration that recognizes objects and collects high-fidelity data about specific objects using the rear-facing camera.
A configuration that tracks only the device’s orientation using the rear-facing camera.
A configuration that tracks only the device’s position in 3D space.
A configuration that tracks the position of a device in relation to objects in the environment.
Add visual effects to the user’s environment in an AR experience through the front or rear camera.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
